p:
Unraveling the mechanisms behind the selection of particular plants for cultivation and domestication is key to understanding the origins of dry-land farming in North China, one of the earliest independent domestication centers in the world
1 . While pioneering research focused on the domesticated millets, recent research on archaeological plant remains indicates more complex patterns of foraging before domestication, with other grasses, in addition to wild millet, likely exploited as food sources
2– 9 . Research must now be directed toward the human choices that led to the favoring of wild millet’s cultivation and domestication as a food source.
